newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentina says beef gets U.S. authorization.
newsitem.headline: Argentina says beef gets U.S. authorization.

text.p: The U.S. government will publish regulations Thursday granting permission for imports of fresh Argentine beef, Argentina's Agriculture Secretariat said Tuesday.
Imports will be allowed to begin 60 days after the publication of the new regulations, the Secretariat said in a news release.
The U.S. decision to grant sanitary approval for imports of a 20,000-tonne annual quota of fresh beef will end a 67-year-old ban on beef shipments from Argentina.

The United States first said it would approve the quota several years ago. But the lengthy process before final approval has irritated Argentine officials, who recently threatened to take the matter to the World Trade Organization if it was delayed much more.

Argentina was barred for decades from major beef markets by its problems with foot-and-mouth disease, but it was officially declared free of the disease by the International Epizootic Office in Paris at the end of May.

Argentina is now aggressively seeking access to world beef markets, and exported about 500,000 tonnes in both 1995 and 1996. The 20,000 tonnes sold to the United States will not itself signicantly boost exports, but the Argentines see the U.S. stamp of approval as vital in their battle to win access to coveted Asian markets, particularly Japan and South Korea.
The government says there have been no foot-and-mouth outbreaks for three years following a successful vaccination campaign of its 50-million head herd, one of the largest in the world.
